Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of the Vernalization Regulatory Network in the Model Grass Brachypodium distachyon
Award.AbstractNarration: The timing of flowering is critical for plant survival, and in agricultural settings proper timing of flowering is critical for maximal yield. In many plant species, flowering occurs at a particular time of year in response to the sensing of seasonal cues such as changes in the length of day and temperature. This project is designed to further our understanding of how the timing of flowering is regulated by environmental cues at a molecular level in the grasses. Despite the fact that grasses include important food crops such as wheat, rice and corn and potential bioenergy crops such as switchgrass, sorghum and miscanthus, little is known about how flowering is regulated at a molecular level in the grasses. This project will employ Brachypodium distachyon as a model because this grass species exhibits a large range of natural variation in flowering behavior that is genetically tractable, and it is straightforward to identify the genes responsible for genetic differences in flowering among different Brachypodium varieties. Understanding achieved by this project has the potential to inform research designed to improve the productivity of food and bioenergy crops. This project will result in the training of graduate students and postdocs for independent careers in science, and will provide undergraduates with an opportunity to learn about research in genetics, molecular biology and plant biology. Students and postdocs working on this project are also encouraged to contribute to our efforts to bring understanding of plant biology into K-12 classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major developmental change in the life cycle of a plant is the initiation of flowering. Many plant species have evolved the ability to initiate flowering at a particular time of year by monitoring seasonal variables such as changes in day-length or temperature. An example of a temperature response is that certain plants require relatively long periods of cold exposure during winter to initiate flowering the following spring. This acquisition of competence to flower after prolonged exposure to cold is known as vernalization.

This project was a study of how flowering is regulated in the model grass Brachypodium distachyon at the level of the genes and their encoded proteins that are key to flowering control. Many of our major crops are grasses such as corn, wheat, and rice, and the timing of flowering (often referred to as ?heading date? by agronomists) is critical for yield.  

Our work has advanced the understanding of how the timing of flowering is regulated in grasses. We have published ten primary research papers in the scientific literature on these advances. One highlight of this work is that we discovered which of the many photoreceptors in Brachypodium is involved in measuring changes in day-length as it relates to the timing of flowering, and it turns out to be the same photoreceptor in wheat (photoreceptors are the proteins that absorb light and initiate a biological response like vision or flowering). For this and all of our projects on discovering the genes that control important plant processes, we developed, in collaboration with a group at Columbia University, a community resource for gene discovery that facilitates pinpointing a researcher?s gene of interest from the large number of other genes in the genome. We also contributed to the understanding that a particular gene/protein (VRN2) evolved as a flowering inhibitor early in the evolution of grasses, but that its specific role and its regulation has varied in different grass species over evolutionary time and perhaps during crop domestication as well. In Brachypodium and wheat, VRN2 is key to creating a requirement for cold exposure to enable flowering. We showed that Brachypodium can ?remember? exposure to cold; i.e., after exposure to cold the plants are in a state that they can flower (the biological term for this is competence) even if the day-length signal for flowering is received months after exposure to cold had ended. We also further characterized the interplay between the sensing and response to the seasonal cues of cold and day-length, and how this interplay varies in different genetic backgrounds. This study led us to discover a key gene (FTL9) that enables Brachypodium to use the short days of winter as a substitute for sensing the cold of winter in order to become competent to flower. A surprising finding was that FTL9 was related to another gene known as FLORIGEN or FT that actually triggers flowering in all plants; this was an interesting example of how evolutionary change can occur by genes duplicating to provide an ?extra? copy that can change to serve a new role that contributes to species? ability to adapt.  Finally, we have identified several additional components of the system that respond to winter cold exposure in order to permit flowering in the spring. Several of these components are unique to the plant kingdom and their roles had not been previously known.

An important component of this project is the training of the next generation of scientists. This study resulted in the training of two graduate students and three postdoctoral fellows in basic plant genetics, development, and biochemistry; in writing and reviewing scientific papers; and in scientific ethics and community service. The PI, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows have also mentored ten undergraduate students over the course of this award.  This mentoring involves learning about scientific research and also includes safety training and discussions of the nature of science. 

During this award period, PI was active in communicating science. In addition to his departmental science teaching for science majors, he created a course on the nature of science for undergraduates who are not science majors and has taught that course every year. The PI also had a program working with the College of Menominee Nation, a Native American College, and their K-12 schools. This outreach program was about student understanding of plant growth and biochemical processes such as photosynthesis and carbon assimilation and how these processes relate to ecosystem health and productivity and the carbon balance of our planet.
